content.webTitle: British blackberry sales rocket as warm weather delivers bumper harvest

fields.headline: British blackberry sales rocket as warm weather delivers bumper harvest
fields.bodyText: Sales of blackberries grown in the UK have rocketed this year after the warm weather delivered a bumper harvest a month earlier than usual. The old-fashioned fruit is also enjoying a revival as a result of the introduction of much sweeter “snacking” varieties, eaten straight from the punnet, which have more appeal to consumers. Sales have doubled in a year and British blackberry growers expect this year’s crop to break records with shoppers set to buy 2,000 tonnes of the fruit – 82% more than last year’s 1,123 tonnes. Growers and retailers have identified a shift in consumers’ eating habits, with demand for fruit that can be eaten as a healthy snack rather than the cooked with added sugar for pies and crumbles. “British consumers are some of the luckiest in the world when it comes to blackberries,” said Laurence Olins, the chairman of the British Summer Fruits trade body. “The UK is at the forefront of new technologies and breeding methods, resulting in exceptional quality, flavourful fruit. Our growers have seen the market grow substantially in recent years, by more than 70% in the last decade. They are now developing their offer to include sweeter, snacking varieties which will really transform sales and accelerate growth of the category.” Marks & Spencer said sales had risen after it introduced larger and tastier varieties such as Victoria and Incentive, which are double the size of a normal blackberry. Its team has been working with growers over the last three years to develop a extra-sweet variety. “This has been a great year for blackberries. The blackberry variety and warm weather we’ve had this summer has helped to make sure they are the biggest yet and are really super-sweet,” Bill Davies, M&S’s fruit expert, said.
